name: tenyr
body:
### Usage
```
$ tas -ohello.to hello.tas
$ tld -ohello.texe hello.to puts.to
$ tsim hello.texe
hello, world !
```

### Overview
**tenyr** is a 32-bit computing environment with focus on simplicity of design and implementation.

**tenyr** currently provides

* an [instruction set architecture](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/wiki/Assembly-language)
* an [assembler / disassembler (tas)](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/wiki/Assembler)
* a linker (tld)
* a [canonical architectural simulator (tsim)](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/wiki/Simulator)
* an [alternate architectural simulator in Haskell (htsim, by Forest Belton)](https://github.com/forestbelton/htsim)

shows progress on

* a [standard library](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/tree/master/lib)
* a [Forth environment](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/tree/master/forth)
* a [synthesisable HDL implementation](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/tree/master/hw/verilog)

and aspires to achieve

* a [C compiler](https://github.com/kulp/toycen)
* a novel operating system

The novel **tenyr** architecture is a two's complement, 32-bit, single-core, modified Harvard architecture. It is intended that **tenyr** be useful as a didactic tool.

**tenyr** is made available under the [MIT license](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/blob/master/COPYING), and is Copyright 2011-2012 [Darren Kulp](mailto:darren@kulp.ch) and [contributors](https://github.com/kulp/tenyr/blob/master/CREDITS).
